title: Chat restrictions
body: Chat restrictions are dumb learn to use the mute button snowflakes.

replies.body:
> ...learn to use the mute button...

Muting and reporting are not mutually exclusive functions. For all you know, they could've done both. So, now what? They muted you, and they also reported you, so they don't need to "learn" anything new.

> Chat restrictions are dumb...

Well, if you don't want to be chat restricted (and potentially, eventually banned), you should consider following the [rules you agreed to](https://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/legal/termsofuse#code-conduct) at account creation and whenever a new patch drops.

If you don't break the rules, you won't get punished. Simple as that.

They are exclusive because 1 youve muted the person they cant do anything to you chat wise if you disagree on something and 2 its just league.
Riots rules are being followed nothing offensive. Stating someone is playing bad is fact not prejudice.

> They are exclusive because 1 youve muted the person they cant do anything to you chat wise if you disagree on something and 2 its just league.

You don't seem to understand what mutual exclusivity is. Basically; performing one function (muting a player) does not prevent you from performing the other function (reporting a player) as well. Meaning that a player could mute you, and then after the match, report you, because muting doesn't block them from reporting.

> 1 youve muted the person they cant do anything to you chat wise if you disagree on something...

Again; muting doesn't preclude reporting. Even if Player B can no longer affect Player A through chat after being muted, Player B can still be reported for the behavior that affected Player A enough to have to mute them as well as any behavior that Player A did not see due to the mute.

If someone _has_ to mute you, then you're doing something wrong.

> ...and 2 its just league.

1) That doesn't suffice as an argument, much less explain how you believe muting and reporting are mutually exclusive.

2) League has rules, and if you break those rules, you can be punished.

> Riots rules are being followed nothing offensive.

Clearly not if you got chat restricted. If you want your behavior peer reviewed so that you can see exactly where you crossed the line and how, you'll want to submit the chat logs associated with your punishment.

Otherwise, do bear in mind that _you_ do not get to decide whether or not you breached the rules; Riot does. Their IFS deemed your behavior as in breach of the rules, and you were consequently punished.

> Stating someone is playing bad is fact not prejudice.

No, but it can still be inflammatory and harassing behavior.

Stating facts can be inflammatory but isnt something to be at fault for.
Player A could have offended Player B or they could have not. Riot has no idea. Only way to confirm it is to ask Player B. Something Riot doesnt do.

> Only way to confirm it is to ask Player B.

_Or Player B could file a report._

> Stating facts can be inflammatory but isnt something to be at fault for.

I disagree. If there's no beneficial purpose to it, why say it? Are they magically going to get a Pentakill if you tell them they're bad? Would someone magically lose weight just because you called them fat? And, more importantly: **_Did they ask for your opinion of their performance?_**

If the answer to those questions is "no", then, guess what; you're at fault for being inflammatory.

They should file one then but Riot acts without a care as to the person they are pretending to defend.

As someone affected by their performance  yes i do get an oppinion on the matter as it affects the goal of the game, winning.
And yes if someone is doing bad say so, they might not know it and can ask for tips/ help.

That didn't answer my questions. I didn't ask if you felt you should have an opinion on other people's performance or whether you think you should chime in, my questions were as follows:

1) Does simply telling someone that they're doing bad immediately improve their performance?

2) Did they ask for your opinion?

If you're not gonna answer these questions, however rhetorical they may be, then I'll simply bow out.

1) A chance it might is better than no chance at all.

2)They are my teammate their performance matters to me fortunately or unfortunately.And matters for obatining the goal. If someone was playing bad the others wouldnt bat an eye if it didnt affect the team as a whole.

Well, you still didn't directly answer question 2, but regardless, here's the part that shows the rhetorical nature of those questions;

The answer to the first question is virtually always going to be "no". For starters, people don't react positively to negative stimuli. As in, if you insult someone and tell them they're bad at the game, they're not going to react well - and that negative reaction to a negative stimulus typically involves playing _worse_, whether intentionally or not. Tilt is a thing, after all.

Beyond that, though, simply telling someone that they're bad isn't constructive criticism, so it functionally has _zero_ chance of getting them to improve. All they get out of it is that _one person_ thinks that they're bad. They aren't told how, they aren't told what to improve on, so they _can't_ improve, and consequently, will not care to try.

As for question 2, the answer to that one is virtually certain as well; if you got punished, then the odds are _extremely frickin' high_ that you gave your opinion to someone who didn't ask. And an unwanted opinion, particularly a negative one, is a negative stimulus. And as above, people do not react positively to negative stimuli.

If you want someone to improve, calling them bad is the worst way to do it. It's entirely counterintuitive, and also plainly inflammatory.

The answer is No only if you endit at "you are bad" which even if it was the case it is that players responsability to care and ask how to improve/ take the subsequent advice.

So telling them they are good when they arent is helpful how? Or not telling them anything? How is that better?If you are going to be silently infuriated by their actions isnt that plainly inflamatory aswell? Worse the lack of action might as well be  you surrendering. Either call them out on their bullshit, lie to them and or let them lose your game with 0 action taken by anyone else on the team to correct them.

You sure paint a pretty picture.

> The answer is No only if you endit at "you are bad" which even if it was the case it is that players responsability to care and ask how to improve/ take the subsequent advice.

And why should they ask? All you're doing is telling them that they're bad. They're not going to want to listen to you, because, again, as I've stated twice before; **_they're not going to respond well to negative stimuli, and they didn't ask for your opinion in the first place._**

They're not obligated to ask, no more than you're obligated to give.

> So telling them they are good when they arent is helpful how?

Nowhere did I suggest telling someone that they're good when they aren't performing well.

> Or not telling them anything?

As the old saying goes, "If you can't say anything nice, then don't say anything at all". Though in this case; if you can't communicate with others constructively, then keep your opinions and advice to yourself.

> If you are going to be silently infuriated by their actions isnt that plainly inflamatory aswell?

If you're not harassing/insulting them, then no, staying silent would not be inflammatory.

> Worse the lack of action might as well be you surrendering. Either call them out on their bullshit, lie to them and or let them lose your game with 0 action taken by anyone else on the team to correct them.

Alternatively, you could simply focus on your own performance instead of trying to excuse your want to flame someone.

At any rate, I can't see much more room for productive discussion here. If you're going to keep harassing players by calling them bad and giving them unwanted opinions of their performance, you're going to continue to get punished - and those punishments _can_ and _will_ reach the point where you get banned.

I'll be bowing out now, so have a good day.

That's what chat restrictions are meant to convey, and if they don't like it then ideally they should work on fixing the behavior that got them that punishment rather than crying foul when they're held accountable for it.

By itself that's true, but it becomes an issue if you're flooding the chat with those messages. If they wouldn't answer you the first two or three times you asked then chances are they won't the next 10 times you do. Likewise calling someone bad 10+ times throughout the game isn't solving anything and is only making you look bad. At that point it's better to focus on your own game rather than on others.

>Muting someone is one and done. You're not one to judge if someone else gets bothered.

If that's the case then why are there people who use chat to intentionally try to provoke and get a rise out of others? They could be using chat for tracking cooldowns, enemy champ/ward locations, things of that nature, but instead they're using it to try to tick others off while using the excuse "well if you don't like it mute me" to try to justify their behavior. Yes people should mute when need be but it's not a get out of jail free card and is meant to be a band-aid solution at most.

>The chat restriction system doesnt really do anything. It just says someone didnt like you. It REFUSES to argue its point(given its a bot) in the context of the match and just flags words. Its more of an effort in frustration than anything worthwhile for the player. Oh you may or may not have offended someone(that person isnt going to confirm it, hell he doesnt remember 99% of the time it even happened, hence he never cared) by way of checking for flagged words. Here is a restriction for you to play effectively without discord. Try to not offended someone randomly by guessing his feelings through a monitor. Good luck. If i was to go further its kind of ablelist in design. Like how would a player on the spectrum be judged by this bot?

Fun fact: During the Tribunal (which is what the IFS is based on) and players could vote to punish/pardon a case with end-game stats and fully ally/enemy chat very rarely did the context matter as everyone is responsible for their own behavior.

As for the CR being a point of frustration for the person in question, that's the point. It's not meant to be pleasant, it's meant to convey the consequences of chat misuse by limiting the amount of messages they can send at a time & hopefully encourage them to be more mindful of what they choose to convey through it. Again it's not about being offended, it's meant to get the person in question to use chat more responsibly and not to abuse/harass others or get into game-long arguments with other players.
